abstract_summ: Given the large requirement of SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis and considering that RNA extraction kits are in short supply, we investigated whether two commercial RT-qPCR kits were compatible with direct SARS-CoV-2 detection from nasopharyngeal swab samples.This method bypasses the RNA extraction step; it leads to a higher amount of available viral RNA compared to the automated extraction methods, and generates the same profile in the subsequent amplification phase.In this study, we compared direct rRT-PCR method (without RNA extraction) using SeeGene AllplexTM 2019-nCoV rRT-PCR with the RealStar® SARS-CoV-2 rRT-PCR kit (Altona Diagnostics).We show that one of the tested kits is fully compatible with direct SARS-CoV-2 detection suggesting that omission of an RNA extraction step should be considered in SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis.Herein, we assessed the RNA extraction necessity, by comparing RT-qPCR efficacy in several direct approaches vs. the gold standard RNA extraction, in detection of SARS-CoV-2 from laboratory samples as well as clinical Oro-nasopharyngeal SARS-CoV-2 swabs.
title_summ: Absolute quantification and degradation evaluation of SARS-CoV-2 RNA by droplet digital PCRA streamlined approach to rapidly detect SARS-CoV-2 infection, avoiding RNA extractionSARS-CoV-2 detection from nasopharyngeal swab samples without RNA extractionPooled RNA extraction and PCR assay for efficient SARS-CoV-2 detectionSARS-CoV2 quantification using RT-dPCR: a faster and safer alternative to assist viral genomic copies assessment using RT-qPCRImproved and Simplified Diagnosis of Covid-19 using TE Extraction from Dry SwabsOptimization of SARS-CoV-2 detection by RT-QPCR without RNA extractionEvaluation of commercial qPCR kits for detection of SARS-CoV-2 in pooled samplesAn alternative workflow for molecular detection of SARS-CoV-2 - escape from the NA extraction kit-shortageEvaluating the efficacy of RT-qPCR SARS-CoV-2 direct approaches in comparison to RNA extractionComparison of SARS-CoV2 N gene real-time RT-PCR targets and commercially available mastermixesOptimizing RT-PCR detection of SARS-CoV-2 for developing countries using pool testingAn alternative workflow for molecular detection of SARS-CoV-2 – escape from the NA extraction kit-shortage, Copenhagen, Denmark, March 2020RT-qPCR Testing of SARS-CoV-2: A PrimerSARS-CoV-2 detection by direct rRT-PCR without RNA extraction
title_abstract_phrases: This method bypasses the RNA extraction step; it leads to a higher amount of available viral RNA compared to the automated extraction methods, and generates the same profile in the subsequent amplification phase.Given the large requirement of SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis and considering that RNA extraction kits are in short supply, we investigated whether two commercial RT-qPCR kits were compatible with direct SARS-CoV-2 detection from nasopharyngeal swab samples.Evaluating the efficacy of RT-qPCR SARS-CoV-2 direct approaches in comparison to RNA extractionSARS-CoV-2 genetic identification is based on viral RNA extraction prior to RT-qPCR assay, however recent studies support the elimination of the extraction step.We show that one of the tested kits is fully compatible with direct SARS-CoV-2 detection suggesting that omission of an RNA extraction step should be considered in SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis.A streamlined approach to rapidly detect SARS-CoV-2 infection, avoiding RNA extractionIn the current pandemic, the presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in samples by nucleic acid (NA) molecular analysis is the only method available to diagnose COVID-19 disease and to assess patients' infectiveness.
